V. Nagar, Puducherry 605 014, India ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +91 413 2654709; fax: +91 413 2655987. Graphical abstract A new strategy has been proposed and tested by DFT calculations for the reduction of N2 to NH3 and N2H4 by H2 under normal experimental condition using [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst. The calculated reaction Gibbs free energy profile indicates that the proposed methodology is viable. The direct contact of H2 with Schrock catalyst can be avoided by using organic co-catalysts to prevent the competition in binding between N2 and H2. Highlights ► A new strategy has been proposed for the reduction of N2 to NH3 and N2H4 by H2. ► The calculated free energies show that the formation NH3 is more viable than the N2H4. ► Formation of six coordinate [Mo]-H intermediates have also been predicted. ► The direct contact of H2 with [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst can be avoided. A new methodology is proposed and tested by Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations to reduce N2 to NH3 and N2H4 using H2 in the presence of [Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] and organic co-catalysts under mild experimental conditions. The calculated Gibbs free energies of the fundamental reactions to form various intermediates and transition state molecules suggest that the proposed catalytic cycle is viable to produce NH3 and N2H4, however NH3 formation is more feasible than N2H4. Formation of six coordinate [Mo]-H intermediates have also been predicted. The direct contact of H2 with [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst can be avoided by using organic co-catalysts to prevent the competition in binding between N2 and H2 with [Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst. Keywords Nitrogen fixation Reaction mechanism Homogeneous catalysis Density functional calculations Molybdenum 1 Introduction Formation of NH bond to yield ammonia from N2 and H2 at low temperature and normal pressure is a long time challenging mission for chemists [1–9]. Although Haber-Bosch technology produces more than 100 million tons of ammonia annually for various applications [10,11], this process requires high energy input and drastic experimental conditions which are great issues as per the consternation of energy saving [12]. Due to this reason, there is an urgency to discover a new viable homogeneous catalyst which can operate under mild experimental condition to produce ammonia from N2 and H2. In this regard, Hidai et al. reported a reaction of Chatt complex (cis-[W(N2)2(PMe2Ph)4]) with trans-[RuCl(η2-H2)-(dppp)2]X (X=PF6, BF4, OTf, BPh4) to generate ammonia and uncharacterized tungsten species under normal (1) (2) { [ P 2 N 2 ] Zr } 2 ( μ - η 2 - N 2 ) ⟶ Toluene H 2 { [ P 2 N 2 ] Zr } 2 ( μ - η 2 - N 2 H ) ( μ - H ) (3) [ ( η 5 - C 5 Me 4 H ) 2 Zr ] 2 ( μ 2 , η 2 , η 2 - N 2 ) ⟶ 85 ° C H 2 ( η 5 - C 5 Me 4 H ) 2 ZrH 2 + NH 3 ( 10 − 15 % ) (4) (5) ( [ Mo ( N 2 ) 2 ( PNP ) ] 2 ( μ − N 2 ) ) + 6 CoCp 2 + 6 LutH + ⟶ rt , 20 h Toluene 2 NH 3 ( 49 % ) + H 2 ( 37 % ) experimental conditions (Eq. (1)), in this reaction, Hidai and co-workers could utilize only H+ from H2 [13]. Fryzuk et al. reported a room temperature reaction of [[P2N2][Zr]2(μ-η2-N2)] (P2N2 =PhP(CH2SiMe2NSiMe2CH2)2PPh) with dihydrogen to form [[P2N2][Zr]2(μ-η2-N2H)(μ-H)] over the period of one week (Eq. (2)) [14]. Although there is no ammonia production in Fryzuk et al. report, this reaction is an important one due to the formation of new N-H bond by the direct addition of H2. Chirik et al. reported a direct reaction of [[(η5-C5Me4H)2Zr]2(μ2,η2,η2-N2)] with dihydrogen to produce ammonia (yield 10–15% with respect to the concentration of dinitrogen complex) at 85°C (Eq. (3)) [15]. Leitner et al. attempted theoretically to use H2 to reduce the N2 to yield ammonia using [M(H)2(H2)(PXP)] (MFe, Ru, Os; XN, O, S) and found more thermodynamic barriers for most of the fundamental steps in their proposed catalytic cycle [16]. However, no reports available till date for the catalytic generation of ammonia from the reaction of N2 with H2 under mild experimental conditions using homogeneous catalyst. On the other hand, Schrock et al. (Eq. (4)) [17–25] and Nishibayashi et al. (Eq. (5)) [26] have reported Mo complexes to produce ammonia catalytically (TON=4) by the addition of proton and electron source under mild experimental condition. Several theoretical calculations have been reported concerning the preeminence of [N2-Mo{(N(HIPT)CH2CH2)3N}] (HIPT=hexaisopropylterphenyl-triamidoamine) catalyst [27–34]. Nevertheless, the catalytic efficiency of [N2-Mo{(N(HIPT)CH2CH2)3N}] catalyst was observed to be lowered by the addition of H2 directly to the reaction medium [35]. Leitner et al. theoretically attempted to use H2 directly to reduce the coordinated N2 in Schrock model complex and found more barriers for their approach [36]. Herein we report our new strategy to utilize the dihydrogen along with [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst to produce ammonia and hydrazine under normal experimental conditions. Already we have tested this methodology for Chatt type complexes [37,38]. Furthermore this new methodology requires less energy input than calculated in the previous report [27]. 2 Theoretical methods The model systems 1–11, 4a-7a, TS-I, TS-II, TS-III, TS-Ia, TS-IIa, Lut, LutH+, [B(C6F5)3], [HB(C6F5)3]−, N2, N2H4 and NH3, have been fully optimized using the B3LYP method [39–41]. The valence orbital and ECP of molybdenum were described using the LANL2DZ basis set [42–45], nonmetal centers were described using the 6-31G* basis set [46–50]. As reported previously, the B3LYP combination with LANL2DZ basis set can be used to describe transition metals and nonmetal centers to produce more reliable results [51]. However, we also tested this method by computing previously reported data by Tuczek et al. for the similar type of calculations and found similar barriers (Table 1 ). We have modeled the [N2-Mo{(N(HIPT)CH2CH2)3N}] catalyst by hydrogens in the place of bulky HIPT (hexaisopropylterphenyl-triamidoamine) substituent in order to reduce the computational time. It has been observed previously that the replacement of bulky HIPT substituent by hydrogen does not change the reaction pattern and also observed similar results for the Chatt type complexes when phenyl rings were replaced with hydrogens [27,52–54]. Vibrational frequency calculations were performed on these optimized structures to confirm minimum energy geometries by observing all positive frequencies, except for the transition state structures (TS) and obtained the zero point energy (ZPE), and thermal correction. A solvent correction (for heptane) was performed using the polarized continuum model (PCM) [55–57]. We have optimized all the model systems with two different spin states (doublet and quartet), however we found that thermodynamically systems with doublet spin state is more stable than the quartet except model system 1 (Tables S1 and S2). We have constructed energy profiles based on the energies obtained from the fully optimized geometries only (using B3LYP/6-31G*/LANL2DZ) and not done any single point energy calculation. We have also constructed energy profiles using the energy of quartet spin state of model system 1 and the overall barriers are found to be comparable with the energy profiles constructed using the energy of model system 1 with doublet spin state (compare Figs. 1 and 2 with Figs. S1 and S2). All these computations were carried out using the Gaussian 03 program [58]. 3 Results and discussion Our proposed catalytic design and computed energy level diagram are given in the Scheme 1 and Fig. 1 respectively. DFT calculations have been carried out on complexes 1–11, 4a–7a (energies and selected geometrical parameters are given in Tables 2 and S1 see Supporting Info.) and transition state structures (TS-I, TS-II, TS-III, TS-Ia and TS-IIa). Reaction of B(C6F5)3 and Lut (Lut=2,6-Me2C5H3N) with H2 at room temperature and normal pressure is known to yield [(C6F5)3BH]− and [LutH]+ as a complex in toluene [59]. In our proposed catalytic design, we used [(C6F5)3BH]− and [LutH]+ to donate protons and hydrides to the [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst to produce ammonia and hydrazine. Reaction of complex 1 ([Mo] ([Mo]=[Mo(N3N)])) with dinitrogen to yield complex 2 ([Mo]-N2]) is calculated to be exergonic by 15.97kcalmol−1, which indicates that the complex 2 ([Mo]-N2) is thermally stable toward the loss of N2. Addition of [LutH]+ to the complex 2 ([Mo]-N2]) to yield complex 3 ([[Mo]-NNH]+) is slightly endergonic by 9.95kcalmol−1 and this can be attributed to the moderate activation of coordinated N2. Addition of [(C6F5)3BH]− to the complex 3 ([[Mo]-NNH]+) to produce six coordinate complex 4 ([H-[Mo]-NNH]) is calculated to be endergonic by 1.64kcalmol−1 in which new [Mo]-H bond is formed (Fig. 2). The formation of TS-I from complex 4 ([H-[Mo]-NNH]) for the hydrogen migration from Mo center to Nβ is endergonic by 21.58kcalmol−1 and this can be achieved under normal experimental conditions. However, the overall barrier to reach TS-1 from complex 3 ([[Mo]-NNH]+) is endergonic by 23.6kcalmol−1 and this would be a rate determining step for the overall processes. Since the overall barrier is also less than 25kcalmol−1, TS-1 can be reached thermodynamically. The formation of complex 5 ([[Mo]-NNH2]) from TS-I is calculated to be highly exergonic by 45.94kcalmol−1 due to the strong affinity of Nβ toward proton (Fig. 1). Addition of [LutH]+ to complex 5 ([[Mo]-NNH2]) to yield complex 6 ([[Mo]-NNH3]+) is calculated to be endergonic by 4.17kcalmol−1. In complex 6 ([[Mo]-NNH3]+), although the Nβ is converted to NH3, the NN bond cleavage is not observed (Fig. 1). Reaction of [(C6F5)3BH]− with complex 6 ([Mo]-NNH3]+) to yield molybdenum–hydride complex 7 ([H-[Mo]-N]) (Fig. 2) and one equivalent of NH3 via N-N bond cleavage is calculated to be strongly exergonic by 40.59kcalmol−1 (Fig. 1). The hydrogen migration from Mo center to the nitride in complex 7 ([H-[Mo]-N]) to form TS-II is endergonic by 4.41kcalmol−1 only (Fig. 1). And the formation of complex 8 ([[Mo]-NH]) from TS-II is calculated to be exergonic by 29.80kcalmol−1 because of the formation of N-H bond of the electron rich nitride. Protonation of complex 8 ([[Mo]-NH]) by the addition of [LutH]+ to yield complex 9 ([[Mo]-NH2]+) is further found to be exergonic by 26.59kcalmol−1. Reaction of complex 9 ([[Mo]-NH2]+) with [(C6F5)3BH]− to generate molybdenum–hydride complex 10 ([H-[Mo]-NH2]) (Fig. 2) is thermodynamically feasible (exergonic) by 6.71kcalmol−1 and the formation of TS-III for the migration of hydrogen from Mo center to the NH2 is endergonic by 15.61kcalmol−1 (Fig. 1). The complete hydrogen transfer from TS-III to form complex 11 ([[Mo]-NH3]) is calculated to be exergonic by 16.01kcalmol−1. Finally, the loss of ammonia from complex 11 ([[Mo]-NH3]) to regenerate complex 1 ([Mo]) to complete one turnover is calculated to be slightly endergonic by 8.15kcalmol−1, which is similar to the previously reported barrier by Tuczek et al. for the same reaction [27]. In order to understand the preference of binding of N2 over H2 and H− with proposed Mo catalyst the following reactions have been computed (Eqs. (6)–(10)). The dinitrogen binding is relatively more exergonic than H2 binding with Mo center (Eqs. (6)–(8)); however H2 binding may interfere in the reaction and this can be minimized by keeping H2 in the form of salt as we described in Scheme 1. The hydride binding with Mo center is found to be more endergonic (Eq. (9) and (10)) and therefore hydride binding may not be feasible when compared to dinitrogen binding. (6) [Mo]+N2 →[Mo]-N2, ΔG o =−15.97kcalmol−1 (7) [Mo]+H2 →[Mo]-H2, ΔG o =−9.30kcalmol−1 (8) [Mo]-N2 +H2 →[Mo]-H2 +N2, ΔG o =6.68kcalmol−1 (9) [Mo]+BH− →[Mo]-H− +B, ΔG o =31.39kcalmol−1 (10) [Mo]-N2 +BH− →[Mo]-H− +N2 +B, ΔG o =47.37kcalmol−1 [Mo]=[Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}], BH− =[BH(C6F5)3]−, B=[B(C6F5)3] We also have examined the formation of hydrazine (Fig. 3 ). The formation of TS-Ia (Fig. 3) from complex 4 ([H-[Mo]-NNH]) for the hydrogen migration from Mo center to Nα is endergonic by 8.67kcalmol−1. The formation of complex 4a ([[Mo]-NHNH]) from TS-Ia is calculated to be highly exergonic by 22.55kcalmol−1. Protonation of complex 4a ([[Mo]-NHNH]) on Nβ by [LutH]+ to yield complex 5a ([[Mo]-NHNH2]+) is highly exergonic by 38.42kcalmol−1. Addition of [(C6F5)3BH]− to the complex 5a ([[Mo]-NHNH2]+) to generate molybdenum hydride complex 6a ([H-[Mo]-NHNH2]) (Fig. 3) is calculated to be endergonic by 14.30kcalmol−1. The formation TS-IIa (Fig. 3) from complex 6 ([H-[Mo]-NHNH2]) by migration of hydrogen from Mo center to the Nα is endergonic by 15.34kcalmol−1. The complete hydrogen transfer from TS-IIa to form molybdenum–hydrazine complex 7a ([[Mo]-NH2NH2]) is calculated to be exergonic by 15.29kcalmol−1. Finally, the loss of hydrazine from complex 7a ([[Mo]-NH2NH2]) to regenerate complex 1 ([Mo]) is calculated to be endergonic by 9.59kcalmol−1. 4 Conclusions In summary, with the help of DFT calculations, a new methodology has been applied to reduce the dinitrogen using H2 in the presence of [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] and organic co-catalysts under normal experimental conditions to produce ammonia and hydrazine. The calculated energies of the fundamental reactions to form various intermediates and transition state molecules (TS-I, TS-II, TS-III, TS-Ia and TS-IIa) suggest that the proposed catalytic cycle is thermodynamically feasible to produce ammonia and hydrazine. We also have observed the formation of six coordinate molybdenum–hydride complexes (4, 7, 10 and 6a) in the new proposed catalytic scenario, which is not known in the previously reported catalytic cycle for the [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst. The direct contact of H2 with [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst can be avoided by using organic co-catalysts to prevent the competition in binding between N2 and H2 with [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst. Since our calculation shows the feasibility of generating ammonia from N2 and H2, the [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst can be an alternate for the Haber-Bosch technology once if this methodology is proved experimentally and observed more TON. coredata.dc:description: A new methodology is proposed and tested by Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations to reduce N2 to NH3 and N2H4 using H2 in the presence of [Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] and organic co-catalysts under mild experimental conditions. The calculated Gibbs free energies of the fundamental reactions to form various intermediates and transition state molecules suggest that the proposed catalytic cycle is viable to produce NH3 and N2H4, however NH3 formation is more feasible than N2H4. Formation of six coordinate [Mo]-H intermediates have also been predicted. The direct contact of H2 with [N2-Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst can be avoided by using organic co-catalysts to prevent the competition in binding between N2 and H2 with [Mo{(NHCH2CH2)3N}] catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Reduction of N2 by H2 to NH3 and N2H4 using [MoL] (L=triamidoamine) and organic co-catalysts: A theoretical approach
